answers.answer: As long as your cat is eating and does not have a gastrointestinal problems, such as gastritis, vomiting, diarrhea, etc., it is fine to switch foods.  If this is done very regularly and very often your cat should retain the necessary digestive enzymes to digest all foods without difficulty.  The food should always be of a WET excellent variety, which means: canned, home-made, frozen, raw, etc and NOT kibble.However, cats who are prone to gastrointestinal problems and pancreatitis, or have food allergies, IBD or have diabetes, or other diseases that require strict prescription diet cannot be switched from food to food.

question: Will feeding a variety (brands and flavors) of high-quality cat food be harmful for my cat, eg leading to development of colitis? There is no evidence of diarrhea or lack of appetite from any of the food I have been feeding my cat, but I have been told by someone (who was told by their vet) that is is unhealthy to feed a variety and cats should be fed only one type of food due to sensitive digestive systems. I was under the impression that if the cat has not developed an allergy to a particular type of protein, variety will give a more balanced diet.Can you advise which is the truth, if it is that simple?
title: Feeding a variety of cat foods
